div.p: A SHORT AND eaſie introduction to Chriſtian faith: Conteining the ſumme of the principles of Religion, neceſſary to be knowne of all before they preſume to receiue the Sacrament of the Lords Supper: SET DOWNE IN queſtions and anſwers, and diſtinguiſhed into Chapters.
AT LONDON Printed by Robert Waldegraue, and are to be ſold at his ſhop in Paules Churchyard at the ſigne of the Crane.

q.p: Bleſſed is the man that findeth wiſedome, and the man that getteth vnderſtanding.
For the merchandize thereof is better than the merchandize of ſiluer, and the gaine thereof is better than the gaine of gold.
Length of daies is in hir right hand, and in hir left hand are ryches and glory.
She is a tree of life to them which laie hold of hir, and bleſſed is hee which reteineth hir.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE Margaret counteſſe of Cumberland, my very good lady, H. G. vvisheth comfort and ioy in the Holie ghoſt, vvith continuance and increaſe of all ſpirituall graces and bleſſings for the ſuſteining of faith in this preſent vvorld, and in the vvorld to come eternall felicitie in the kingdome of heauen.
div.p:
THe wiſe man in a moſt heauenly and deuine prouerb, as moſt wiſely by his extraordinary wiſedome, ſo moſt truly by the inſtinct of the ſpirit, wherwith he was inſpired, in writing that booke, hath commended it to all poſteritie that the feareProu. 3. 7. Pſa. 111. 10 of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge, the meditation whereof, and of ſuch like places of holy ſcripture no doubt (right H. and my very good La.) did firſt worke in your ſelfe, an earneſt deſire to know and fear God: & after, that godly & zealous care which your Ho. carieth toward your whole family (whereof I my ſelfe vpon certaine experience can giue teſtimony) that they might be inſtructed & taught in the knowledge and feare of God. This zeale & carefulnes though it be commendable in al, yet it is ſo much the more commendable, as the perſon in whom it appeareth, is in hier and greater place, & therfore they alſo vnto whom the Lord hath giuen honor & hath exalted & ſet them aboue other, are eſpecially boūd in regard of their places & the goodnes of god ſhewed to them, to rēder thanks to the Lord, by ſhewing obedience to him, & hauing careful ouerſight of them which are vnder their autority & gouernmēt: the which the Lord hauing giuen you to ſee, & in ſome good meaſure to deſire to practiſe, & to make an open profeſſiō of the zeale of gods glory, ſo that the ſame therof is ſpred in moſt places of this land (I hope to the ſturring vp of many by your good example and to the propagation of the praiſe & honor of God) it ſtandeth more neerly vppō you to labor, to continue, & to go forward, & increaſe in that zealous & godly profeſſion of the ſinceritie and
truth of religiō, that God of his goodnes hath more mercifully dealt with you, may be more glorified by you thā by others vpon whom he hath not beſtowed like graces & bleſſings, & hereof great numbers which onely haue by conſtant report hard of you, do aſſure themſelues & aſſiſt you with th • ir faithful praiers. And I for mine own part at this preſent (whom it hath pleaſed the right Ho. my Lord, & your La. by the prouidence of God to place ouer your family) as a teſtimony & witnes of your zeale & care of religion, which is better known to me then to others, haue cauſed this ſhort Catechiſme & ſum of religion to be publiſhed, which I offer vnto your honor as the greateſt new yeeres gift which my ſmall power in ſo ſudden and ſhort time could preſent you withall, hoping that it ſhalbe accepted in good part, not for the woorthineſſe of it, but in conſideration of the occaſion, the purpoſe, and the end your La. had in moouing me to write it. In the handling thereof, as your deſire was, I haue labored for breuitie, and by queſtions & anſwers haue obſerued that method which is moſt eaſie & plaine. If by the mercifull goodnes of God (as my deſire & praier is) this ſhort and little treatiſe may redound to the benefit of your familie in regard of that end wherevnto it eſpeciallie aimeth; and if your Ho. vnto other your diuers & manifold tokens of your good acceptation of me continually ſince my firſt comming into your houſe ſhal adde this, to accept in good part my indeuors and purpoſe, I ſhall thinke my ſelfe abundantly & fullie rewarded, and haue iuſt occaſion offered to aſcend praiſe & glory vnto the Lord, whoſe deuine maieſty from the bottome of my heart I moſt humbly beſeech to grant vnto your honor continuance of health & welfare, and the vſe of all thoſe his gifts and benefits, which both concerne the goods of this life, and eſpeciallie the atteining of life euerlaſting.

closer.signed: Your ladiships humble bounden in the Lord Ieſus, H. Graye.

div.head: Of the Creation of al things, and fall of man. CHAP. 1.

sp.speaker: Queſtion.
sp.p: WHat thinke you of the frame of this world, and of all things therin, haue they not beene for euer?

sp.speaker: Anſwere.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How were they then firſt made?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: God who is without beginning, & onlyGene. 1. euerlaſting, in the beginning made all theſe things which you ſee.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat is God?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: God is a ſpirit, infinit, eternall, vncreated,Iohn. 4. Iere. 23. 24 Apoc. 1. Gene. 1. Iere. 10. 23 Prou. 2. 30 31 Iam. 1. 17. creator and gouernor of all things, without qualitie or quantitie, without ſhadow or change: who is in his eſſence or being infinitlie mightie, iuſt, mercifull and good, and therefore made all things good, and ruleth all things well.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Is there but one infinit & one God?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No: but there be three perſons in theMat. 28. 19 Iohn. 1. 17. 14 24. Pro. 8. 2 Matt. 3. 17. Ioh. 15. 26. ſame Godhead, the father of himſelfe alone, the ſonne begotten of the father before all beginning, the holie ghoſt proceeding from the father and the ſonne.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVherfore did God make the world and all creatures therein?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: To ſet foorth his glorie.Prou. 16.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Seeing God, who is onelie God and without corruption, made all things, how commeth it to paſſe, that euil is come, and the world & all creatures in it are ſubiect to corruption?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Man for whom all things were eſpeciallieGen. 3. made, by the ſuggeſtion of ſatan tranſgreſſing the commandement of god broughtRom. 1. ſinne into the world, & by ſinne death entred vpon all his poſterity, who had ſinned in him, and moreouer by him the creatures wereRom. 8. made ſubiect to vanitie and corruption.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVherefore is the cauſe of ſinne and corruption imputed vnto man.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Becauſe God hauing made man afterGen. 1. his owne image, and giuing him free will and power to continue in that perfect eſtate wherin he was created, he notwithſtanding, abuſing his free will & power which he had to the committing of ſin, is moſt iuſtly to be accounted the cauſe of all ſin, & the excluſion of himſelfe & al his poſterity out of paradiſe.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat call you the image of God?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Perfect vprightneſſe and integritie inEph. 4. Gal. 2. bodie and ſoule.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: In what caſe dooth man ſtand now by meanes of Adam his fall?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: We are by nature bondſlaues of ſin & ſatan,Rom▪ 3. Eph. 2. & the children of wrath & condemnation.

div.head: Of the reſtoring of man. CHAP. 2.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: DOoth man remaine ſtill in that damnable eſtate wherevnto Adam by his fall brought him?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: God forbid.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How thē is the caſe altred with man?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: God by his infinit wiſdome, of his only free mercie & goodnes hath ſo diſpoſed, ordered & turned the fall of Adam to the good of his elect children, that their eſtate after thisRoman. 4. life in the kingdome of heuen ſhalbe a great deale more happie & bleſſed than if they had liued in paradiſe.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: By what meanes dooth the Lord worke this?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: By fulfilling his promiſe in ſending theGeneſis. 3. Cor. 1. 15. ſeed of the woman to conquer ſatan, ſin and death, & to ſet vs free frō them, & to purchaſe for vs euerlaſting life in ye kindom of heauē.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVho is the ſeede of the woman?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Chriſt Ieſus perfect God & perfect mā, God in that he is of like ſubſtāce, equall maieſtie,Philipp. 2. eternity & power with his father. Man in that he is the ſeed of the woman, & tooke the whole nature of man vpon him.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVas it neceſſarie that our ſauior and redeemer ſhould be both God and man?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVhy ſo?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: If he had bin man alone, he could not haue paid the ranſome for ſin, & ſatiſfied the infinit wrath of God, but ſhould haue beene ſwalowed vp of death, bicauſe man was ſubiect to death. And againe, if he had bin GodRom. 4. alone, he could not haue ſuffered death, therefore it was requiſite, that hee ſhould be both God and man, man, that he might die, God, that he might ſuſtaine and vpholde the manhoode,Gal. 3. to ouercome and vanquiſh death.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: But is it now true, that curſed is hee that dooth not all things which are written in the booke of the law?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yes verily.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How thē ſhal we be freed frō this curſe?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: By the death and obedience of IeſusGalat. 3. Chriſt: he hath by his death ſuffered the torments of hell for our ſin, & by his obedience performed the whole law for vs.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: But how dooth that profit vs which Chriſt did in his owne perſon?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Chriſt is ours by the gift of God, andRoman. 8. whatſoeuer Chriſt did, hee did not for himſelfe, but he that knewe no ſinne was made ſin for vs, that wee might be the righteouſneſſe2. Cor. 6. of God by him.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: By what meanes are we made partakers of Chriſt and his benefits?Gala. 3. 26. Epheſ. 1.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
Onelie by a true faith, whereby wee
receiue Chriſt.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What is faith?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: It is an vndoubted and certaine perſuaſion of the loue of GOD towardes vs inRom. 8. 38 39. & 26, 11 Chriſt Ieſus grounded vppon the promiſes of God, made vnto vs in the goſpell, wherbyRoman. 8. wee are aſſured, that our ſins are remitted, & we by the ſpirit of god working in our harts are made the adopted children of God.

div.head: Of the triall of our ſelues whether we be the children of God, or no. CHAP. 3.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: HOw ſhal we know that we haue faith?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: By proouing our ſelues whether wee2. Cor. 13. 5 be in the faith, or whether Chriſt Ieſus be in vs or not.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How ſhall wee prooue our ſelues?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: By the working of the ſpirit in vs, forRom. 8. thoſe which are the children of God, are led and gouerned by the ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How ſhall we know that the ſpirite dwelleth in vs, and that we haue faith?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: By the effects and fruits of the ſpirit,Gala. 5. 21. which are loue, peace, long ſuffering, &c. and according to the rule of ſaint Iames: ſheweIames 2. me thy faith by thy works, and I will ſhewe hee my faith by my works.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Are works then neceſſarie to ſaluatiō?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yea but not as cauſes of our iuſtification, but as effects and teſtimonies of our faith, and the way which the Lord hath preparedEpheſ. 2. wherein we ſhould walke and glorifie him, til he bring vs to his kingdom of glory.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How is this faith begotten in vs?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The ordinarie meanes is the woordeRoma. 10. Rom. 1. 18. 1. Pet. 1. 23 preached.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Can not they then be ſaued which either haue not the vſe of the word, or els refuſe it?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: God forbid that wee ſhoulde iudge or condemne any, for the Lorde can ſaue extraordinarily without meanes, and hee dooth not call all at all times.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Is it no ſinne therfore to refuſe the worde?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yes it is a fearefull and dangerous ſin, refuſing the word, and as much as in vs lieth we debarre our ſelues of our ſaluation.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What cal you the word, the preaching wherof you make the inſtrument and meanes to beget faith?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Generally the whole ſcripture which is conteined in that booke commonly called the Bible, but eſpecially the goſpel, wherin theſe cauſes are comprehended wherevpon our faith is grounded.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What is the ſpeciall vſe of the preaching of the law?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: It is a forcible meanes to humble vs by the threatnings of the ſame, and it is aGalat. 3. ſchoolemaiſter to prepare vs, and make vs fit to receiue the goſpell, and Chriſt Ieſus which is offered vnto vs by it.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: HOw manie things dooth this worde of God generallie taken teach vs principallie?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Theſe foure: firſt, obedience to the law of God: ſecondly, praier, which is a part of the worſhip and ſeruice of god: thirdly, faith in Chriſt: fourthlie, the Sacraments which are ſeales & pledges of the doctrine of faith.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How do you diſtinguiſh theſe foure things according to the vſuall and common diuiſion of the woorde into the law and the goſpell?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The firſt two inferre vnto the law, and the laſt two vnto the goſpell.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How is the law diuided?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Into two tables: Exod. 31. 18. 34. 7.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat is conteined in the firſt?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Our duetie which we owe vnto God, and what ſeruice and worſhip we are to performe vnto him.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat is conteined in the ſecond?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Our dutie toward our neighbor, and how we ought to behaue our ſelues towards him ſo long as we liue in this world.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many cōmandements be there?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Ten.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many perteine to the firſt table?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The firſt foure.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many to the ſecond?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The laſt ſix.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Rehearſe the commandements.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: God spake theſe words, and ſaid: Thou ſhalt haue no other gods before me, &c.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What is the end and fulfilling of all theſe commandements.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Loue: 1. Tim. 1. Gal. 5. Matth. 22. Nom. 13. Mar. 12.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Is it poſsible for vs to fulfill all theſe without breaking anie one of them?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No, though we do what we can, yet weMat. 15. 19 Rom. 17. 18. 19. breake them dailie and hourelie in thought word and deed.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What puniſhment then is appointed for the breakers of theſe cōmandements?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The curſſe of God which is eternallDeu. 17. 26 Mat. 25. 41 deſtruction both of bodie and ſoule.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How ſhall we then eſcape this puniſhment?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
Chriſt became accurſſed for vs to deliuerGala. 3.
vs from the curſſe, and hath nailed that hand-writing which the Lorde had againſt vs vpon the croſſe, and hath made a ſhewe and triumphed openly ouer death, and ouerColoſſ. 2. the curſſe where vnto we were ſubiect.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: WHat doe wee owe vnto the Lord for this worke of our redemption and our deliuerance from the curſſe?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Al honor, al praiſe, al glorie, al thankſgiuing.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How ſhal we giue theſe to the Lord?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: By praier which is vnfained, and proceedeth from a true and liuelie faith.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What thing is praier?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: It is an humble lifting vp of our harts and ſoules vnto the Lorde, whereby wee eyther make requeſt for things neceſſarie concerning this life and the life to come, or elſe giue thanks vnto God, for benefits and graces receiued.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How manie things doe you gather out of this deſcription of praier?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
I obſerue theſe three things: firſt, to whom we muſt pray: ſecondly, for what wee muſt pray: thirdly, the diſtinction or diuerſitie
of praier.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: To whom muſt we make our praiers?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: To God alone.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Maye wee not praie to Angels or ſaincts?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No: for that is flat idolatrie.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What reaſon haue you to proue this?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: To giue that to the creature which is proper and peculiar to God, is manifeſt idolatry,Reue. 9. but praier is a part of ye ſeruice whichPſal. 11. is dew only to the Lord, therefore to giue it to the creature, it is idolatry.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Are not the angels miniſtring ſpirites for the vſe of man?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yes: but we haue no commandement or warant to pray vnto them, for wee muſtPſal. 61. Rom. 10. cal vpon him in whom we muſt beleeue, but we muſt beleue in God only & therfore pray vnto him alone and not to angels or ſaincts.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: For what cauſe we pray?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: For all things neceſſarie both for this life and the life to come.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Muſt we pray for earthly and for ſpiritual things after the ſame maner?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
No: we muſt pray for earthly things with exception and condicion, ſo far forth as they ſhall ſtand with gods glory & our good, & ſaluation, & thus wee muſt pray for riches, for helth, for proſperity, &c. but we may pray
for ſpiritual & heauenly things abſolutely & without condicion, as for faith, ſanctificatiō, wiſedome, and ſaluation, for theſe things are alwaies ioyned with the glorie of God.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How is praier diſtinguiſhed?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Into a petition and thankeſgiuing.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What is a petition?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: It is a ſute & requeſt which we make vnto the Lord for ſuch things as we ſtand in need of.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat is thankſgiuing?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: It is to acknowledge the Lord to beeIames. 1. 1. Cor. 4. 7. the author and fountaine of all goodnes and that we receiue al good things from him.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: For what muſt you giue thanks?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: For all benefits both corporal and ſpirituall.Epheſ. 5. Ierre. 2.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat call you corporall benefits?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: All thoſe which concerne our bodies & the vſe of this life.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhich call you ſpirituall?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Al thoſe which concern the welfare of the ſoule and our eternal ſaluation, as namely, our redemption & deliuerance from death which we mentioned in ye beginning of this ſection, and all other good graces & benefits which concerne life euerlaſting.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How muſt wee pray vnto God, or giue thanks vnto him?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: With the ſpirit of our minds, for godIohn 4. is a ſpirite.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What maner of mind, or with what affection muſt we pray?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: In the affection well diſpoſed vnto praier, theſe foure things are required firſt,Luk. 18. 13 that we renounce our ſelues, and whatſoeuer is in vs, and throwe downe our ſelues before the throne of the maieſtie of God, acknowledging and confeſſing our owne ſins and vnworthineſſe: ſecondly, that wee prayIame. 1. in faith: thirdly, that wee haue a feeling ofve. 6 our miſeries, and of the wants and neceſſities for the which we pray, and that we haue an earneſt deſire to obtaine them: fourthlie, that we come vnto the Lorde with vnfainedMar. 9. 24. repentance and purpoſe of amendement of life, for the Lord promiſeth no bleſſing to any, but to ſuch as are his children, and haueRoman. 8. a care to walke in his feare.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What forme of praier muſt wee vſe?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: That eſpeciallie which our Sauiour Chriſt himſelfe hath preſented vnto vs in the ſixt of Matthew, and ſecond of Luke.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: May wee not vſe an other forme of praier beſides this?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
We may vſe an other forme of words, but the matter of all our praier muſt be examined and limited according to this forme,
wherein in generall terms is ſet downe by the wiſeſt that euer was, nay wiſedome it ſelfe, what things we muſt pray for, both concerning this life and the life to come.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Repeat this forme of praier which we cal the Lords praier.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Our father which art in heauen, &c.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Shew me briefly the ſumme and the meaning of this praier.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
This praier conſiſteth on thoſe two parts, firſt, a preface in theſe words, Our father which art in heauen, then the praier it ſelfe in the words following: the preface teacheth vs two things, firſt, what GOD is in reſpect of vs, to wit, a louing father, who as a father tendreth his children, and will not denie him any thing which he hath neede of: ſo the Lord is moſt readie and willing to giue vnto vs ſuch things as are neceſſarie for vs if we aſke them by faith: ſecondly, in ye laſt words of this preface, to wit, which art in heauen, we are taught what God is in reſpect of himſelfe. The examination of the place where the Lord is ſaid to be (not that1. King. 8. Acts 1. Eſa. 16. he is indeede contained in any place, or can be, bicauſe he is infinit) doth argue ye power, the maieſtie, the might of God whereby we are ſure that the Lord is able to grant vs al our requeſts. This preface then doth make
much for the ſtrengthning of our faith, whē we conſider, that God is a father, and therfore willing, and he dwelleth in heauen, and therfore is able to giue vs euery thing wee aſke. The praier it conſiſteth vpon certaine petitions, and a concluſion annexed to them: the petitions which are ſixe in number be of two ſorts, the firſt three concerne the glorie of God, the laſt three our owne wants and neceſſities, the order of the firſt three lieth thus: firſt we pray for the glorie of GOD which is the end of all things, that we may celebrate and ſanctifie the name of God: in the ſecond we pray for the meanes that wee may do this, that Chriſt woulde rule by his kingdome in our hearts, and by the working of his ſpirite, thorough the miniſterie of the word, wold be at downe in vs al ſin & wickednes, & raiſe vs vp to ſanctification & holines of life: in the third, that wee may haue aſſurance that we performe both the former, we pray that the wil of god may willingly and readily be done of vs, as the angels doe it in heauen. The order of ye three laſt lieth thus, in the firſt wee pray for al things requiſite & neceſſarie for the maintainance & ſuſtenance of this life: in the two laſt we pray for ſpirituall things, & ſuch as concerne life euerlaſting: in the fift petition we pray for remiſſion
and pardon of our ſins through Chriſt Ieſus,Apo. 20. 27 21. 17 without the which we cannot enter into the kingdome of heauen: in the laſt, that the Lord woulde not giue vs ouer vnto ſatan, or ſuffer vs to be ouercommed of temptations, but would deliuer vs from the diuell, and all euil which might hurt & indanger our faith, if the Lord ſhold leaue vs and ſuffer them to rule and tyrannize in vs. The concluſion is For thine is the kingdome, &c. which is added for the confirmation and ſtrengthning of our faith, & containeth three arguments: the firſt the Lord is our king, for he wil be mindfull of vs and prouide for his poore ſubiects: ſecondly, he hath al power, and therfore he wil ſhew it in helping and defending his church & granting his children their requeſts: thirdly, to him apertaineth & belongeth al glory, & therfore that his children may glorify him he will giue them ſuch things as they ſhall ſtand in need of, Amen, which is as much as ſo be it, is added for two cauſes: the firſt is to ſhew wt what deuotion or affection we muſt pray, that is, with an ardent & earneſt deſire: ſecondly, with what aſſurance & confidence, to wit, with full perſuaſion that the lord wil grant our deſires.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p:
Do you ſay in this your explication of the lords praier, that the three firſt petitions
concerne Gods glorie, and the three laſt our owne neceſsities?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: But doe not all concerne the glorie of God which you haue ſaid to be the end of al things?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The firſt three concerne only the glory of God, the laſt 3 do concerne alſo ye glory of God, but ſo that we alſo pray moreouer, for thoſe things which are needefull for vs both for our ſoules and bodies, that wee by them, and in them we may glorifie God.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: WHat is the third principal thing which the word teacheth vs?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The doctrine of faith in Chriſt Ieſus.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Vnto what part of the word do you referre this?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Vnto the goſpell.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat is the goſpell?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: It is the glad tidings of ſaluation, & that heauenlie doctrine which teacheth vs how to beleeue to obtaine eternall life thorough Ieſus Chriſt onely.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Is there not a ſumme of the cheefe points of the Goſpell collected and ſet downe ſhortly and briefly?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat call you it?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The apoſtles creed.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhy is it ſo called?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Becauſe as ſome thinke it was made by the apoſtles, but rather becauſe it agreeth with their doctrine and that beleefe which they preached in their time.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Rehearſe the articles of the creed.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: I beleeue in God the father almightie, &c.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How is this creed diuided?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Into twelue articles.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many things doo theſe articles teach vs principally?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Foure.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Which be they?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Firſt we are taught what to beleue of God the father in the firſt article. 2. What to beleeue of God the ſonne in the ſix next. 3 What to beleeue of God the holy ghoſt in the eight article. 4. What to beleeue concerning the church in the foure laſt articles.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What doo you beleeue of God the father?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Firſt I beleeue that he is my father inEſay. 69. 6. Rom. 58. his ſonne Ieſus Chriſt. 2. That he is the founteine of all things, and the maker & creator of them. Laſtlie, that he is almightie,Iob. 31. 2. and hath power to doo all things, and without his prouidence nothing can be doone by men, by angels, or by the diuels in earth, heuen, or in hell.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p:
What doo you beleeue concerning
the ſecond perſon in trinitie.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: I beleeue that he is Ieſus, that is my ſauior and redeemer. 2. That he is Chriſt,Matth. 1. 1. that is the annointed king, preeſt & prophet. 3. That he ſuffered the torments of hell forPhil. 1. me vpon the croſſe, and truly, and not feinedlie, died for my ſins, & roſe again from death for my iuſtification. 4. That he is aſcendedRom. 25. Acts. 1. vp into heauen, & there ſhall remaine till the latter day, and then he ſhall come accompanied with the holy angels to iudge ye world.Mat. 25. 32

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What doo you beleeue of the holie ghoſt?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Firſt that he is God. 1. Pet. 1. 2. Eph. 4. Acts. 5. 3. 4 Luke. 1. 15 Iohn. 3. 5. 1. Cor. 5. 5. 28. Secondlie that he doth ſanctifie me, & make me a new creature, and aſſure me of my ſaluation.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What doo you beleeue concerning the church?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
I beleue that Chriſt hath, and hath had, and ſhall haue till the end of the world in all places, and amongſt all ſorts of men, hisAct. 10. 34. Eph. 5. 34. 1. Cor. 12. 12. 13. 14. 1. Cor. 10. 2. Cor. 11. 28. Galat. 1. 2. Eſa. 53. 4. 5 church, that is a company of elect & faithfull people, which haue a ſocietie & fellowſhip amongſt themſelues, as members of one head whereby they communicat all benefits both ſpirituall & temporall, to whom the Lord giueth remiſſion & pardon of ſins in this life, and in the world to come life euerlaſting after
that he hath raiſed them vp from ye dead.1. Ioh. 2. 8. 1. Cor. 15. 53. 54. 1. Theſ. 4. 14 1. Cor. 15.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: By what meanes doo we apprehend and atteine to this which you haue now confeſſed.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The ordinarie way is the hearing and preaching of the word of God, whereby the holie ghoſt dooth worke faith in our heartsGal. 1. 2. 3. to apprehend & vnderſtand effectually theſe articles of ſaluation.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: HAth the Lord appointed vnto his church no other means to helpe and ſtrengthen faith by but his word?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yea, our ſauior Chriſt prouiding for our weakenes & infirmities, hath giuen vnto vs outward and viſible ſignes, which do repreſent, and as it were, ſet before our eies & ſences, for ye confirmation of our faith, the truth, and if I may ſo ſpeak for more plainnes, the eſpeciall matter of this whereof you haue now made confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What call you theſe ſignes?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Sacraments.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat is a ſacrament?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: It is an outward and viſible ſigne inſtituted and ordained of the Lord to confirm the promiſes and couenants of God made to vs in the goſpel in the hearts of the faithful.Gen. 17. 11

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What doo you learne out of this definition.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Theſe three things. Firſt that it is a ſigne of another thing which is ſignified. 2. That euerie ſacrament muſt haue his inſtitution of the Lord. 3. That it is a pledge or ſeale of the promiſe of ſaluation.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Why doo you ſay this is a ſigne?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Becauſe it is a thing which the Lord ſetteth before mens eies, to ſignifie a thing which is not ſeene,

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: why muſt it be inſtituted of god only?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: He only muſt appoint the ſeale and the ſigne which giueth the promiſe, but God onlie maketh the promiſe of ſaluation, & therefore he onelie hath authoritie to ordeine the ſacrament or ſigne.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Why ſay you that it muſt be a pledge or ſeale of the promiſe of ſaluation.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Becauſe it is giuen vs of the Lord for the confirmation of our faith, which is groū ded vpon the promiſe of ſaluation.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Are all theſe things neceſſarilie to bee obſerued in euery ſacrament.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat accoūt do you make of thoſe fiue which the papiſts haue added, namelie the ſacraments of penance, abſolution, confirmation, laieng on of hands, extreme vnction, and matrimonie.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: That account which the word of God teacheth me to make of them, that they are no ſacraments, becauſe theſe three things which are neceſſarily required in euerie ſacrament, are not to be found in any of them.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How many ſacramēts do you make thē?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Two.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhich be they?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Baptiſme, and the Supper of the Lord.1. Cor. 10.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat is Baptiſme?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: It is a ceremony inſtituted of Chriſt inMatth. 18. a viſible ſigne of water to ſignifie our remiſſion of ſins, and reconciliatiō which we haue with God by the blud of Ieſus Chriſt which is ſhed for vs.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: what do you conſider in this definitiō?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Theſe two things (which are alſo to be conſidered in the Supper of the Lord) I obſerue for the true vſe of the ſacrament. Firſt what is the ſigne. Secondly what is ye thing ſignified.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: what is the ſigne in baptiſm?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Water.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What is the thing ſignified?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Remiſſion and pardon of ſinnes by theAct. 22. Marke. 14. bloud of Ieſus Chriſt.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: In euery ſacramēt there muſt be a reſemblance & proportiō betwixt the ſigne & thing ſignified, tell vs therfore what it is in this ſacrament of Baptiſme?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
As the water dooth waſhe awaie the
filthineſſe of the bodie, ſo our ſoules beingTi. 3. 6. 5. 6. Ephe. 5. 20 1. Pe. 1. 1. 2. 1. Iohn. 7. ſprinckled with the bloud of Ieſus Chriſt waſhed and purged from the filthineſſe and pollution of ſinne.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Is there any difference betwixt water in baptiſme and other water?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Not as concerning the ſubſtance, but they differ in the vſe: for common water ſerueth to waſh the bodie, but water in Baptiſme is a Sacrament of the waſhing of the ſoule,

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVherefore are we but once baptized ſince we are commanded oftentimes to receiue the ſupper?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Becauſe, as circumciſion was to theGen. 17 Iewes, ſo baptiſme is to vs an entrance and admiſſion into the church of god, and it is ſufficient for vs once to be admitted into gods familie, and therfore as they were but once circumciſed, ſo wee muſt be but once baptized: yet that we may remaine and continue in this familie and church of god, it is neceſſarie that wee be fedde oftentimes, and therefore we muſt often receiue the Sacrament of the ſupper, as the Iewes did alſo eueryExod. 12. yere celebrate the paſſeouer.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What is this ſupper of the Lorde which is the other ſacrament?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
It is a ceremonie inſtituted of our
ſauiour Chriſt a little before his death in viſibleMat. 25. ſignes of bread and wine, to teſtifie and repreſent vnto vs his paſſion and bloudſhedding, whereby he ſuffred the torments of hel for our ſinne.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What bee the ſignes in this Sacrament?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Bread and wine.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat is the thing ſignified?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Our redemtion and deliuerance fromPhil. 8. eternall death and hell by the ſuffering and bloudſhedding of Ieſus Chriſt vppon the croſſe.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat is the reſembling and proportion betwixt the ſigne and the thing ſignified?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: That as our bodies by the hand and mouth receiuing theſe outward things of bread and wine are therby nouriſhed indeed, ſo aſſuredly wee apprehending by faith theIohn. 6. 35. Mat. 26. 26 Rom. 4. 23. 1. cor. 30. 2. cor. 5. 21 paſſion and bloudſhedding of Ieſus Chriſt, our ſoules are thereby nouriſhed and fed to eternall life, hauing our ſins remitted, and Chriſts death & righteouſnes imputed to vs.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What doeth the bread ſignifie?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The body of Chriſt.1. cor. 11. 24

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What doth the wine ſignifie?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: The bloud of Chriſt.1. Cor. 11. 25

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p:
Why hath the Lord iuſtituted two
ſignes in the ſupper, and but one in baptiſme?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: As our bodies are not ſuſtained by meat only, but alſo by drinke, ſo the Lorde would aſſure vs that we are not fed to halfs, as it were, but Chriſt hee is both meat and drinke vnto vs.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Is the bread and wine in the Sacrament the ſame with other commō bread and wine?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: They are the ſame in ſubſtance and1. Cor. 10. 16. 17. 18. 1. Cor. 11. 26. Mat. 26. 28 nature, but the holie vſe wherevnto they are applied, make them differ from common bread and wine.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Is not the bread turned into the bodie of Chriſt, and the wine into the bloud of Chriſt?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: But doth not our ſauior Chriſt ſay, this is my bodie, when he gaue the bread, and this is my bloud, when hee gaue the wine?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yea, but they are figuratiue ſpeeches attributing the name of the thing ſignified, vnto ye thing ſignifieng, as alſo in the old ſacraments. Circumciſion was called the couenant which was but a ſigne of the couenant,Gene. 17. Exod. 12. 1. Cor. 10. and the paſchall lambe was called the paſſeouer, and the rocke was called Chriſt.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: VVhat is the reaſon why the ſigne is called by the name of the thing ſignified?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Becauſe we ſhould lift vp our minds from theſe earthly and corporal things vnto the heauenly and ſpiritual things which are ſignified by them.
To what end doe we receiue this ſacrament of the ſupper?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: For theſe three cauſes principallie.Mal. 26.
Firſt, for the redemtion and ſtrengthning of our faith.
Secondly, for a teſtification of our obedience1. Cor. 11. 26. Mat. 26. and thankefulneſſe vnto God for the worke of our redemption.

Thirdly, for increaſe of loue and amitie,1. Cor. 10. 17. 1. Cor. 12. 13. 1. Cor. 11. 33. Epheſ. 4. 5. for there is alwayes a communion of ſaints in the church of God, which eſpecially conſiſteth in this, that all the children of God are members of the ſame bodie, and partakers of the ſame Sauior and Redeemer Ieſus Chriſt.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Seeing the bodie of Chriſt is in heauen, and we are on earth, how are we partakers of it?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Thorough a true and a liuelie faithIohn 3. 17. which diſcendeth and taketh hold of the mercies of GOD in the merites of Chriſt Ieſus.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: That we may be woorthy communicants of this ſacrament, how muſt we prepare our ſelues vnto it?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: We firſt muſt try & examine our ſelues concerning the doctrine of a ſacrament whether we do rightly vnderſtand or conceiue of it or no. Secondly alſo concerning our maners & life, whether we be fit to receiue it at the time appointed.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How muſt we examine our ſelues cō cerning the doctrine▪

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: By entring into conſideration of that which ye holy ghoſt hath written & ſet downe of it, whether we do fully vnderſtand & know it, and whether our hearts and conſciences can willingly ſubſcribe and yeeld vnto it which is taught to be the truth of it.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Is this examination of our ſelues cō cerning the doctrine neceſſary?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: Yea, otherwiſe how ſhal we know how to behaue our ſelues in this holy action, except we know what it is that we do, and for what end and purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How muſt we examine our ſelues cō cerning our maners and life, whether we be fit to receiue this ſacrament or no?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: By prouing our ſelues whether we be2. Cor. 13. 5. 1. Cor. 11. 28. the members of Chriſt or no.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p:
How ſhall we know this great ſecret
and myſterie.

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: If we haue faith and repentance.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How ſhal I decerne that I haue faith?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: If in my heart I be aſſuredly perſuadedEphe. 1. 13 2. Cor. 1. 22. 5. 5. Rom. 8. 15. Ephe. 3. 12 1. Iohn. 2. 1 Eſay. 53. 6. Epheſ. 17. 18 by the working of the ſpirit in me, that the puniſhment of my ſin is fully diſcharged in Chriſt, and that whatſoeuer he hath done perteineth not onely vnto others but euen to me.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: How ſhall I know that I haue true repentance?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: If I be inwardly and heartily ſorrowfullMat. 26. 75 Iere. 4. 4. Ioel. 2. 12. Rom. 6. 45. 6. 7. Phil. 3. 13. 14 for my ſins, and doo moſt willingly confeſſe them vnto God, with full deliberacion and purpoſe of amendment of life, & an earneſt deſire to mortifie and kill ſin in me, and wholy to conforme my ſelfe to too the will of the Lord.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: What if I find not theſe things in me, what counſell giue you me?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p:
Not to preſume to come to this table of the Lord, for he that eateth and drinketh1. cor. 11. vnwoorthilie (that is, without faith and repentance, whileſt he is a wicked liuer, a profane perſon, a blaſphemer, &c. and hath not repented him of his ſins, with full purpoſe to renounce them, and liue alwaies after in the feare of God) he eateth and drinketh his owne condemnation, not decerning the body
of Chriſt aright.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.p: Is it a thing left to our choiſe and libertie whether we will come to the ſupper or not?

sp.speaker: A
sp.p: No, the holie ghoſt in forbidding men to come thither vnworthily commaundeth al them which haue diſcretion and iudgement, to examine diligentlye, and prepare themſelues, that they may come worthily vnto it: ſo that if wee do abſent our ſelues, and neglect this preparation & making of our ſelues readie to come vnto it, let vs feare leaſt we become contemners of it, and ſo depriue our ſelues of that great benefite which is offered vnto vs by it.
